Introduction











The
responsibility for a person’s education rests first with family and
later with the individual himself or herself, but it is such an
important issue and so complex that most homes and most individuals
need help.  Governments help, especially with education for the

title: 06 Community
summary: This extensive document (spanning ~5800 words) provides comprehensive history of Black River as Don recalls it. Coverage includes the physical geography of the river, early settlement by United Empire Loyalists and Scottish settlers post-1776, the progression from forestry to farming, and economic activities including shipbuilding, lumber, and fishing. Don documents place names (Upper Black River, Middle Black River, Little Branch, Fowlie's Mill, McKenzie Settlement), major institutions (four schools, two churches, community hall), the mill economy (Fowlie's gristmill and sawmill, John W. MacNaughton's operation), and the impact of WWII on community stability. He includes personal economic data from his brother Walter's 1947-48 record book showing butter prices (45 cents/lb), egg prices (30 cents/dozen), and woodcutting/threshing crew practices. The document captures Don's detailed knowledge of community infrastructure and traditional rural life before modernization.
content_preview:
THE COMMUNITY OF BLACK RIVER IN 1939







Although these notes focus on the community in 1939, a bit of background may be in order.




The Black River




The Black River is about 7 miles south of Chatham, New Brunswick and, like most rivers in Eastern New Brunswick, flows from west to east eventually emptying from the south into Bay du Vin which is part of the Miramichi River estuary.  Black River is thought to have received its name xxx.  The Eastern boundary of the Black River was the Victoria Bridge near its mouth although technically the river extends beyond the bridge before melding with the waters of the Bay du Vin.  The Black River has many tributaries the largest being the Little Black River, better known as Little Branch. Which joins the Black River near its mouth.  




The Black River area was, and to a large extent still is, heavily forested with black, red and white spruce and balsam fir, some pine, white and yellow birch, maple, beech with a scattering of ash, xx.  While the forests were and continue to be significant, Black River began to switch from forestry to farming earlier than some of its neighbouring communities.







A Brief History




Although land had been granted along the shores from Hexham east, settlement of the Black river only occurred after the turn of the century and by 1850 settlers could be found as far west as the Meadows near the headwaters of the river.  




The first settlers were United Empire Loyalists who, after the American Revolution of 1776, sailed north along the New England coast and, for the most part, entered the Bay of Fundy landing at Saint John, New Brunswick.  Many moved up the Saint John River with some crossing to the east coast via the upper reaches of the Miramichi; others came directly to the Miramichi.    Loyalists were soon followed by settlers from the old country - most were Scottish and Presbyterian.  After six to eight weeks on the ocean, they set foot in the New World.  Some after an initial se...

title: 20 East or West
summary: A detailed autobiographical narrative covering Don's 1969 decision to move to Prince Edward Island. Describes his departure from Ottawa's Training Branch (1962-1968) due to restructuring and loss of collegiality, his interview process for a Nanaimo community college presidency, and his deliberate choice to decline British Columbia in favor of PEI after an unsatisfactory conditional job offer. Demonstrates his character: intellectual rigor (organizational theory from Indiana), respect for organizational culture, and principled decision-making. Includes memorable anecdote about the Board's assumption that "given the opportunity, one would choose BC over any other offer."
content_preview:
East or West		







People leave current jobs or positions more often than they seek new ones.  That was certainly the case with my leaving Ottawa in 1969.




By the end of spring semester, 1962, my course work at Indiana University in Bloomington, Indiana, was completed, a thesis topic approved but the actual writing had not started.  Carol had worked ever since we were married, but now we had an addition to our family, a six month old baby boy.  I sought full time work.




Canada had just launched a major program to provide both operational and capital support for technical and vocational training and the Federal Government was adding staff; on July 2, 1962, I joined the Training Branch, Department of Labour in Ottawa.  Most of the people in the Branch were specialists – vocational high school, apprenticeship, educational upgrading, technical training, occupational training and occupational analysis.  My assignment was in the area of vocational teacher training; it was a new initiative and an exciting place to work.




Six years later, however, matching grants had lost favour and a seat purchase arrangement was initiated.  The collegial atmosphere of the Training Branch and the partnership with the Provinces had evaporated.  In fact, the Training Branch was being downsized and perhaps even phased out while training decisions were being made at the Regional level.  Finally, all, or practically all, of the senior staff were replaced and people with a training background were not greatly valued.  In addition, I had lost confidence in the newly appointed Branch Director and began to think about moving.  But where?




In another recollection I told about meeting Dr. Ted Sheffield and learning about the proposed College in Prince Edward Island.  About the same time I learned about and applied for the presidency of a new community college being established in Nanaimo, British Columbia.   It sounded challenging.




An invitation came from British Columbia to partic...

title: 2004-Education or Schooling
summary: A thought-piece dated July 24, 2004, in which Don challenges the common conflation of education with schooling. Drawing on Good's Dictionary and quotations from George Bernard Shaw and Bud MacDougall, Don argues that education encompasses learning from home, church, peers, travel, and community—not just formal schooling. He critiques schools for narrowly focusing on academic disciplines and advocates for including teamwork, problem-solving, and life skills in educational transcripts and student evaluation.
content_preview:
July 24, 2004

3-Education or Schooling







Recently my wife mentioned that a daughter of a friend, or a friend of a friend’s daughter, had difficulty finding a job.  My wife commented further that she was surprised, in that the young lady in question “had a good education”.   I asked, “How do you know?”  My wife replied, “She has a Master’s Degree from” and she named the university.  I responded, “I understand that, but how do you know that she has a good education?”   This points to a very common bit of faulty thinking that permeates the field of education.  We do not confuse hospitalization with good health, religion and church attendance or court appearances with citizenship.  Why, therefore, do we confuse education and schooling?  Is it sloppy thinking or is it a deliberate scheme by educators to blur the lines?




Good’s Dictionary of Education defines schooling as “individual training or education received at an educational institution, military or civilian.”  Education, on the other hand is defined as “the aggregate of all process by means of which a person develops abilities, attitude and other forms of behaviour of positive value in the society in which he lives.”  Obviously schooling is part of one’s experience, and, therefore, part of one’s education.




George Bernard once said, “From a very early age, I had to interrupt my education to go to school”.  Bud MacDougall, an icon of Canadian business now deceased, added, “ I left school at 14 and I’ve regretted it all my life.  Should have left when I was twelve.” I am sure we have all heard the comment that we should bestow a degree on every newborn so that the process of getting an education would not be disturbed in later life.  One might also give each newborn a high school graduation certificate.




I am not knocking the value of schools; they are a major contributor towards one’s education.  But so are the home, church, peers, travel, the community and others.  The popular view is we get our edu...

Donald Glendenning was born and raised in New Brunswick and taught at the elementary, secondary and postsecondary level.  He attended the Little Branch School, is a graduate of the Miramichi Rural High School, Teachers' College and the New Brunswick Institute of Technology (now the New Brunswick Community College) and studied at the University of London (England) on a Lord Beaverbrook Overseas Scholarship.  He holds a B.Sc. and MSc. from Bradley University and a Ph.D. from Indiana University.  Dr. Glendenning taught at the elementary, secondary and post-secondary level, and worked as a training specialist in Ottawa for a number of years with the Department of Labour and the Department of Manpower and Immigration.




In 1969 Dr. Glendenning moved to Prince Edward Island to become the Founding President of Holland College, a college of applied arts and technology.  In this capacity, he played a leadership role in the founding of the College and in implementing competency based education.  The College acquired an international reputation for its innovative approach to education.




In 1987 Dr. Glendenning retired from Holland College and operated a consulting firm with projects both in Canada and overseas.  For a number of years he was a regular contributor to the Canadian Vocational Journal, and edited and published The Family Chronicle and the Community Foundation News.  He also authored and co-authored a number of publications.  His current activities include being a Director of the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, genealogy, gardening and reading.  Dr. Glendenning is the recipient of a number of awards and honours including the Order of Canada, Atlantic Canada Innovator of the Year Award Finalist, and holds an honourary degree from the University of Prince Edward Island.

content_preview:
Donald E. M. Glendenning




Don Glendenning was born and raised in Little Branch, Black River, New Brunswick.  He attended the Little Branch School and is a graduate of the Miramichi Rural High School. 

For a number of years, he taught in New Brunswick, first at Kouchibouguac, then at the Miramichi Rural High School and the New Brunswick Institute of Technology.  After a number of years as a training specialist with the Federal government, in Ottawa, he moved to Prince Edward Island where he was Founding President of Holland College.  On leaving the College, he operated his own consulting firm taking on projects both in Canada and overseas.




His formal studies include Teachers’ College in Fredericton, NB, New Brunswick Technical Institute, the University of London (England), Bradley University and Indiana University where he received his Ph.D.  In 1986 he was inducted into the Order of Canada.  Over the years he was active in a number of National organizations including the Canadian Vocational Association, Association of Canadian Community Colleges, and the Institute of Public Administration of Canada.  




For many years, he was a frequent speaker at conferences, he contributed a regular column to the CVA Journal, edited a newsletter for the Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, published the Family Chronicle, and recounted recollections about life in Black River.




He is currently active in The Community Foundation of Prince Edward Island, tracing his roots, reading and puttering around in his garden.  Lately, he has become a frequent writer of letters to the Editor in support of changes in public education.




Don married Carol Chesney from Peoria, Illinois and they have two children and two grandchildren.

title: 82 Whither bound
summary: Don expresses frustration with education system direction, noting changes often unlinked to improving student skills, knowledge, or attitudes. Reframes education's purpose as helping Islanders develop abilities needed for thriving in daily life, not merely what happens in schools. Questions whether limiting education to government-delivered schooling represents too narrow a vision. Criticizes focus on "excellence" without linking to actual learning outcomes. Highlights Saskatchewan Teachers' Federation calls for shared accountability, provincial education councils, and education hubs. Reviews Hechinger Report's coverage of US education trends and contributes financially to the publication. Discusses CVA-ACFP newsletter focus on teacher competencies and university relevance. Reflects Don's broader systemic critique and search for coherent education vision beyond institutional reporting.

title: 99 -2 Rating Scale
summary: Don recounts observing a handyman's consistent, self-directed, quality work and wonders why schools don't develop similar practical rating scales for employment-bound students and vocational learners. He advocates for rating scales with five or six competency levels that focus on practical attributes (speed, accuracy, initiative, safety, quality) rather than abstract grades. This approach, he argues, enables self-assessment discussion and strengthens soft skills and personal attributes. He also notes Ontario's 2020 math curriculum redesign incorporating financial literacy and coding, suggesting this reflects growing recognition that math education must connect to real-world application.

title: Bertrand Russell
summary: Philosophical piece sharing Bertrand Russell's "Liberal Decalogue" - ten commandments of teaching from his autobiography. Core principles include intellectual humility, truth-seeking over authority, encouragement of critical thinking, reasoned argument over authority, intellectual freedom, tolerance of unconventional opinions, valuing intelligent dissent, truthfulness, and intellectual integrity. Russell emphasizes education should promote questioning, independent thought, and logical reasoning. Values closely aligned with liberal arts education philosophy relevant to college leadership.
content_preview:

Don, Tim, and David,

My
younger sister forwarded the link to this item earlier today.  It's
been floating around in my mind most of the day, so I feel compelled
to share the meme with friends.






-Tom
White-Hassler






A
Liberal Decalogue: Bertrand Russell’s 10 Commandments of Teaching

by
Maria Popova






British
philosopher, mathematician, historian, and social critic Bertrand
Russell endures as one of the most intellectually diverse and
influential thinkers in modern history, his philosophy of religion in
particular having shaped the work of such modern atheism champions as
Christopher Hitchens, Daniel Dennett, and Richard Dawkins.  From
the third volume of The Autobiography of Bertrand Russell: 1944-1969
comes this remarkable micro-manifesto, entitled A Liberal Decalogue —
a vision for responsibilities of a teacher, in which Russell touches
on a number of recurring themes from pickings past — the purpose of
education, the value of uncertainty, the importance of critical
thinking, the gift of intelligent criticism, and more.

It
originally appeared in the December 16, 1951, issue of The New York
Times Magazine, at the end of the article “The best answer to
fanaticism: Liberalism.”














Perhaps
the essence of the Liberal outlook could be summed up in a new
decalogue, not intended to replace the old one but only to supplement
it. The Ten Commandments that, as a teacher, I should wish to
promulgate, might be set forth as follows:

1.
Do not feel absolutely certain of anything.

2.
Do not think it worth while to proceed by concealing evidence, for

4.

I was friends with 2 girls near my age who lived with their widowed mother next door.

We would spend hours playing dressup or store with a play cash register.

title: Boxing Match
summary: Don's vivid childhood memory of June 22, 1938, when Joe Louis defeated Max Schmelling in a famous rematch. Don was eight years old, sitting with his mother across the road from Uncle Jim's house where men gathered to listen to the radio broadcast. The incident captures the excitement of a historic boxing moment during a period of rising anti-German sentiment and Don's childhood in rural New Brunswick.
content_preview:
Boxing Match




June 22, 1938 was a beautiful sunny summer day.  I recall sitting under the apple tree in the front yard with Mum.  Across the road, a few people gathered at Uncle Jim’s to listen to the radio.  Uncle Jim had removed the lower sash of the kitchen window so the men could hear the broadcast better.  It was a rematch between boxing great, Joe Louis, and Max Schmelling.  Mum would not let me go across to listen although I could still hear from across the road.




Feelings ran high.  Schmelling had beaten Louis in an earlier match.  With the saber rattling in Germany, there was much anti-German sentiment.




Round one began; 2.08 minutes later the fight was over.  Louis knocked out Schmelling.  The fight was over.  The men lingered for a few minutes and then went home.

title: Collecting Sap
summary: Brief account of Don's spring chores on the family farm: tapping maple trees on the ridge with his brother Ken, collecting sap in milk cans and barrels, and his mother's labor-intensive process of boiling sap into syrup and sugar. Don recalls his responsibility for keeping the woodbox filled during the long boiling process.
content_preview:
Collecting Sap




We always tapped a few maple trees on the ridge when the nights were cool and the days were warm.  The sap was good to drink but had little if any taste.




I recall occasions of going to the Ridge with Ken early in the morning to empty the sap buckets.  Ken hitched the horse and we took milk cans, of the kind used to ship cream to the creamery and I recall once taking the barrel from the churn to bring the sap to the house.




On occasion, and maybe frequently, Mum would boil the sap to make maple syrup.  It takes a barrel, 45 gallons, of sap to make a gallon of syrup and it seemed to take forever to reduce sap to syrup.  It took even more boiling to reduce sap to maple sugar. Maybe it seemed like a long time because  because it was usually my job to keep the woodbox filled.

title: Dentist
summary: Brief account of Doug Dower, a resident dentist in Black River who operated from David Murdoch's house (north side of river below Uncle Jack Godfrey's property). Don recalls his brother-in-law Cameron Russell and brother Norman visiting Dower for tooth extractions on Sunday afternoons without anesthesia. Dower later closed his office, moved to Chatham, and eventually established a fishing/hunting camp near Horton's Creek bridge.
content_preview:
Dentist




At one time, Black River had a resident dentist in the person of Doug Dower.  His office was set up David Murdoch’s house on the north side of the river just below Uncle Jack Godfrey’s.  I cannot recall whether this was a full-time or part time office.  I do remember, though, that Cameron Russell, my brother-in-law, went to him one Sunday afternoon to have a tooth extracted – extracted, as I recall, without the aid of laughing gas or freezing; Norman remembers going to Doug Dower also on Sunday.  I think that he soon closed his office and moved to Chatham.  Years later, he had a fishing/ hunting camp on the river just above the Horton’s Creek bridge.

title: Elmer

Traces Elmer's work progression: likely started in woods of Maine/New Hampshire (near Skowhegan, Millinocket, Berlin); worked lumbering in New Hampshire with horses, establishing record lumber cut on camp wall (recalled by multiple family members). Notes dam construction work (logging improvement and power generation purposes). Recounts author's 1993 Portland visit finding East Portland/Munjoy Hill completely rebuilt. Places Elmer within context of Maritimer migration wave to "Boston States" for economic opportunity.

content_preview:
Sept 1, 2008

Agricultural Heritage Project




Background notes on the Hallmore Tractor







Hall and Saver was a partnership of Harold Hall and Stafford Stanley established in Charlottetown the 1930s.  They operated a foundry and produced equipment primarily for the agricultural and fishing industry.  Around 1940, they produced a conversion tractor.




Most farm tractors were purpose built, however, during the period, a number of companies built conversion kits that allowed a farmer to convert his auto (whether a Model A, Chevrolet, Oakland or whatever) so that it could be used as a tractor.  The conversion kit usually consisted of a sturdy rear axle with rear wheels having strong cleats/lugs.   




I became aware that such equipment was manufactured in PEI, probably in 2004 but most likely in 2005, through a conversation with Jim Stavert, son of one of the founders of the company.  Jim told me of a phone call from a Mr. Heim from Chicago enquiring about the Hallmore tractor.  




I was curious about the pieces in Mr. Heim’s possession and encouraged Jim to follow up.  In fact, I searched the internet and found an address for Mr. Heim, 15065 Spruce Road, Lockport, Illinois, 60491 and drafted a letter for Jim’s consideration.  Jim revised and sent the letter but there was no response.




The scene shifts to a summer evening in 2006 at my cottage and a conversation with a neighbour, Dr. Arleon Kelley now living in Elgin, Iowa.  Knowing that Dr. Kelley traveled frequently on Interstate 80 between Iowa and Indiana, and that Mr. Heim lived close to that highway, I wondered if Arleon would visit Mr. Heim if the opportunity arose.  On Arleon’s return to Iowa at the end of the summer, he and his wife took time to look up Mr. Heim.  Through a telephone call and later correspondence I learned more about the visit.

title: Little Branch School
summary: Extensive first-person memoir written by Don describing his childhood schooling at Little Branch School in Black River. Details about four one-room schools in the area, daily challenges including lack of running water, physical punishment with strapping, and ingenuity in student life. Notable anecdotes: water carried from Don's house, eating lunch from Dominion shortening pails cooled in the brook, and being contracted to start the school fire at 7:30 am. Describes transition to Miramichi Rural High School in January 1940 with its modern amenities and influence of Macdonald Schools. Sent to Kaye Lister for retired teachers magazine in March 2007.
content_preview:
~~~~~~




As I Recall:




Some memories of the Little Branch School




There were four one-room schools in Black River; I lived near, and attended, the Little Branch School as did my brothers and sisters before me.  Although I lived close to the school, many students lived a mile or more away.  For most students, the Little Branch School provided their entire formal schooling; a fortunate few stayed with relatives and attended high school in Loggieville or Chatham.




The Little Branch School had a pump that didn’t work and a sink that did.  Listening to my older siblings, however, the sink seemed to be used mostly as a place to ‘strap” students who acted out – strapping meant using a 15 inch ruler across a hand held on top of the sink stand.  Drinking water, a pail in the morning and one in the afternoon, was carried from our house by a couple of boys designated for the task each day.  It was more like a half a pail by the time it reached the school, especially if transported down the hill between two boys on a sled.  Obviously there was no water for washing your hands. 




The school was down the hill and on the other side of the cove from our house and in winter, our hill became an extension of the playground.  It was also a favourite place in the community for evening coasting parties.  The rising tide filled the cove twice a day and at least one school mate found himself up to his neck in salt water one noon hour.




Arbour day was special; we trudged to school with rakes, hoes, pails and scrub brushes to help with a spring clean up; we usually finished by one o’clock and were allowed to go home.  




Arbour day was also special because it was the one day of the year I was allowed to carry lunch. My Mother packed a lunch in a 5-pound Dominion shortening pail – red with yellow lettering as I recall. (Some students carried blue-and-white Crisco cans but ours were always a Dominion.). I don’t remember the sandwiches but I do remember the milk. Mum filled an...

title: Near fire
summary: Don recalls a dangerous near-fire in the family home when a cracked furnace allowed flames into the brick chamber while cats disturbed insulation material on top. His brother Kenneth extinguished the fire and the furnace was later replaced with help from Norman MacKenzie.
content_preview:
.




A Near-fire




Ken and I were recalling a near fire at home, I am not sure of the year.  As I recall, Ken, Norm and I were hauling wood one spring day, although there was still lots of snow around.  We were hauling the wood on a large hand-sled, John’s sled we always called it.  Ken smelled smoke and was met by smoke when he opened the cellar door.




At our place, the furnace firebox was set inside a brick box about 5’x5’ x5’.  Another brick wall was built outside the first leaving an air space between the two walls of brick acted as an insulator.  The furnace itself would handle a stick of wood four feet long.  Forming a cap over the furnace was a sheet metal covering with a number of openings to which pipes could be attached to lead the warm air to various rooms above.  On top of the sheet metal was a layer of sand to also act as insulation.  Seems that the cats were playing on the sand on top of the furnace and pushed off one of the covers.  At the same time, the cast iron furnace had cracked allowing flames to enter the chamber.  Something caught fire.  




As I recall, Ken came to the rescue and quickly got pails of water to douse the fire.




It was shortly thereafter, as I recall, they replaced the cast iron furnace.  It was very heavy and they used a rope to hold it back when sliding it down the cellar stairs.  Norman MacKenzie, who was a big, husky man, helped Walter and John ease the furnace down to the basement and replace the old one.

title: St. Paul's Memories of
summary: Don's personal memoir of his early years at St. Paul's Presbyterian Church in Black River Bridge, New Brunswick, written for the church's anniversary. content_preview:
Memories

 of 

St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church

Black River Bridge, NB

July 00, 2023

On this anniversary occasion, I am pleased to provide a few recollections about my life and times in St. Paul’s Presbyterian Church in Black River Bridge, New Brunswick. Although I actually participated in the official opening on July 20, 1930, my memories of the event are a bit hazy.  I understand, however, that older siblings were actually at a church event when I arrived at Little Branch on a Sunday evening a   year earlier.

St. Paul’s played a significant role in our family. My father was involved in its construction; my Mother was an active member, siblings played a variety of roles and nephews and nieces are keeping up the tradition. I might also add that many summer Ministers boarded at our home and shared meals and events with our family; their presence was one of my connections to the world beyond Black River.

Sunday services were held at 11.00 am one week and 7:00 pm the next; the change allowed the minister to travel to and from Kouchibouguac9 (awo-point charge) where the schedule was reversed. After a morning service, the Minister travelled to Kouchibouguac  where he preached the evening service and stayed the following week. In those days, Ministers, did not have their own vehicle; transportation to the other site was provided by members of St.Paul’s.  One summer minister, as I recall, had a bicycle to travel back and forth. 

My church experiences were positive; St. Paul’s was a welcoming church. Sunday services were always warm and friendly (most members were related); there was a positive but muted conversation before the service got under way. men gathered outside for conversation (and perhaps another smoke) prior to the commencement of the service; 

I recall sunny Sundays travelling to and from church with Mother and my siblings in the large “express wagon”; wagon travel was leisurely and allowed for conversation about the just completed service as well family...

content_preview:
Watlings at the Meadows




Janet Watling asked recently about the early Watlings at the Meadows.  It is confusing because, as we know, there were at least three Jubal Watlings.




Jubal 1 married Susan Leach.  I have no evidence that they came to Canada or Black River.




A Jubal Watling, I believe to be Jubal 2 married to Christina MacNaughton,    petitioned (F4243) for 50 acres of land “situate as follows: on the South side of Black River adjoining south of William McBeath’s meadow lot and east of a lot applied for by John Edge.  The petition is dated at Chatham on April 9, 1851 and includes Jubal’s signature.  The property was vacant, surveyed but without improvements.  Other hand written notes on the page are confusing in that they show apparent approval on May 21/1851 and Auction, August 51".  The papers are signed by Peters, the  Deputy Surveyor.  Lot number not given.

The New Brunswick Crown Lands Grant Index shows a grant of 100 acres located at A30 BL. 15 SE SD Black River, Glenelg Parish Northumberland County to Jubal Watling, Jr. on April 20, 1884. (Recorded in vol. 105, No.18287)




This is located in an area known as the Meadows - a name that has long since disappeared.  This, I believe, is Jubal 3 who married Grace MacDonald.  Jubal and Grace moved to Little Branch, in 1900 or 1901 to the place where Neil Watling now lives.

title: Wool and Yarn
summary: Recollections related to sheep farming, wool processing, and yarn production in the Miramichi region. Documents traditional agricultural and textile activities that provided supplementary income and self-sufficiency for rural families.
content_preview:
Wool and Yarn




We always kept a few sheep, perhaps a dozen or so – nor am I sure of the breed although I know they were white.  The sheep had their own shed at the top of the hill where we coasted.  It was easy to climb onto the roof of the sheep shed and jump off into the snow bank, which curled around it.  




Each spring there were new lambs, usually twins but sometimes only one; they always seemed sickly and some had to be nursed with a bottle.  Sometimes they were brought into the house for a few days,  Some died.  But they were cute.  In early summer the sheep had to be sheared.  Sheep shears were hand operated, very sharp and were hinged at one end not hinged in the middle like a pair of scissors.  I never sheared     







sheep but I helped Norman on at least one occasion.  




One put a few boards on top of sawhorses.  Sheep were caught and their front and hind legs were tied together.  Then they were put on the table and sheared.  Norm was pretty good at it although occasionally nicked the skin and drew blood.  Sometimes the sheep had ticks and had to be dusted or sprayed.  They sure looked funny with all the wool removed.  Shearing sheep was a dirty, smelly job partly because the wool was so oily.




I remember Norm bringing home half a dozen sheep in the old Model A.  He had removed the back seat and turned up the seat on the passenger side.




Also in the spring of the year, we docked the tails of the lambs.  Docking meant cutting off their tails to leave only a stub.  This was done with one chop with a sharp axe.  We had small cloth squares, perhaps a 4-inch square, and a bit of grease was put on the cloth and over the end of the stump.  This was used to keep the wound clean. 




After the ground warmed but before the grass grew, it was necessary to wash the wool.  It was a major undertaking.  The bags of wool were opened and the real dirty parts were snipped off and discarded.
